keyTakeAways: Christopher Moynihan, a man pardoned by President Trump after participating in the January 6 Capitol riot, has been arrested for allegedly threatening to kill House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries.
Moynihan allegedly sent threatening texts to Jeffries, stating he would kill him 'for the future' and that 'even if he is hated he must be eliminated.'
The arrest comes amid a broader national concern about rising threats to lawmakers, with Capitol Police reporting a dramatic increase in threat assessment cases.
Moynihan was previously sentenced to 21 months in prison and 36 months of supervised release, and received a full pardon along with over 1,500 others pardoned for Capitol-related offenses.
The pardon of individuals like Moynihan has sparked criticism, with lawmakers arguing that such pardons allow violent offenders to re-enter society without accountability.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Christopher Moynihan, a former participant in the January 6, 2021 Capitol riot and a recipient of a blanket pardon from President Trump, has been arrested on a felony charge of making a terroristic threat against House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries. Allegedly, Moynihan sent texts in which he stated he would kill Jeffries, saying 'I will kill him for the future' and 'even if I am hated he must be eliminated.' The arrest, which occurred on or about October 17, 2025, follows his prior sentencing in 2023 to 21 months in prison and 36 months of supervised release. Moynihan is currently held in the Dutchess County Justice and Transition Center, with bail conditions set at $10,000 cash, $30,000 bond, or an $80,000 partially secured bond. The case has reignited national debate over the implications of pardoning individuals who committed violent acts during the Capitol riot, especially given that others like Matthew Huttle have since been killed following pardons. This incident occurs amid a surge in threat assessments to lawmakers, with Capitol Police reporting over 14,000 such cases by the end of 2025, signaling a heightened risk to public officials.
